body: discussed with @jwfromm offline, could due to different compilers, closing for now
@tqchen : all comments are handled now
You can implement floor like this: https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/floordiv-operation-in-tensors-how-to-achieve/146/5 Then we should not have not-compatibility instruction

Ok, let me try the floor operator addition first. I hope mod division work fine with all platforms by default.
round would be easy if we have floor [ round(f) = floor(f+0.5) ].
thanks, having bilinear upsampling is nice. But what is the use case of asymmetric upsampling (different scales for width and height) ?

Yes, different scale for width and height.

I don't have information on real time models for asymmetric scale.
I am trying to unify the API for all algorithms instead of having multiple operators from frontend to topi.
Unified template would be 
`scale(data, out_shape, layout='NCHW', align_corners=False, mode='NN')`

I felt its easy to maintain with new algorithms in future if required.

Thanks for the review :)

@tqchen Sorry, I can't access the tvm discuss recently, so I'm not sure whether you have replied the tvm.var problem I have met. It seems tvm.var does't work in some condition when generating cuda kernel. The problem can be reproduced by change the sample code 
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/tutorials/optimize/opt_conv_cuda.py:28
to 
`batch = tvm.var('m')`
We are planning to use tvm to accelerate our inference engine, and was blocked by this problem for nearly a month. Any help will be appreciated.

do not include json file in the repo. The test environment do have mxnet installed so you can directly import mxnet
please use https://discuss.tvm.ai/ for general discussions, the support for int8 inference is work in progress and we will put out more resources in next release cycle

This discussion is better suited at discuss forum. We didn't support float to make the FFI interface simple, as double is enough to pass arguments around. It also reflects the fact that python only have int and float types and do not distinguish between float and double

It is possible to support adding list of function names, specifically, we could ask each module to optionally register a function ```___dir___```, which when called, return list of names. We cannot force all the modules to support this though, since we want to keep things minimum.
We need to call some API in mxnet example folder. Or we can export the inference model and save it to somewhere.
OK, then maybe it makes sense to create a github repo, or gist to host the json. In the long term, it would be nice to just use the standard gluon-cv API

cc @nhynes for review. Please add a test case to prevent the problem from happening again

Can we write something like: block = model_zoo.get_model('ssd_512_resnet50_v1_voc', pretrained=True)
net, params = nnvm.frontend.from_mxnet(block)
to directly load ssd model from gluoncv model zoo?
merges https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1173

It seems like that gluoncv implements ssd a slightly different. multibox_detection is split into smaller operators and multibox_prior is replaced by a gluon block. Also the gluon block has three outputs now. In this case from_mxnet(block) will give error. For now maybe we just use the legacy implementation.
In that case, it would be REALLY nice if we could simply upgrade from_mxnet to support the model from gluoncv, this would make user's life much easier

This is the list of operators exported by gluoncv SSD network.

```
      "op": "Activation", 
      "op": "Concat", 
      "op": "Convolution", 
      "op": "Flatten", 
      "op": "L2Normalization", 
      "op": "Pooling", 
      "op": "Reshape", 
      "op": "SliceChannel", 
      "op": "_contrib_box_nms", 
      "op": "_div_scalar", 
      "op": "_greater_scalar", 
      "op": "_mul_scalar", 
      "op": "_plus_scalar", 
      "op": "broadcast_add", 
      "op": "broadcast_mul", 
      "op": "elemwise_add", 
      "op": "elemwise_sub", 
      "op": "exp", 
      "op": "null", 
      "op": "ones_like", 
      "op": "slice_axis", 
      "op": "slice_like", 
      "op": "softmax", 
      "op": "transpose", 
      "op": "where", 
      "op": "zeros_like", 
```
where 
 - "op": "_contrib_box_nms" is a versatile bounding box suppression op extracted from multibox_detection operator.  
 - "op": "slice_like" is used to bypass the infer_shape limitation if image size is not determined. It's a variant of slice so should be very simple to implement.

As long as we have NMS extracted in TVM, we are good to load gluoncv SSD models.
@tqchen : all comments handled except the int64 conversion(waiting for your reply)

Here is a good example for implementing a thread_extent scope that represents the GPU threads.
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/contrib/peak.py#L196
which shows
``` python
def extern(ins, outs):                                          
    # pylint: disable=unused-argument                           
    """construct measurement function by building IR directly"""
    ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()                                
                                                                
    bx = tvm.thread_axis("blockIdx.x")                          
    tx = tvm.thread_axis("threadIdx.x")                         
                                                                
    ib.scope_attr(bx, "thread_extent", n // max_threads)        
    ib.scope_attr(tx, "thread_extent", max_threads)             
                                                                
    idx = bx.var * max_threads + tx.var                         
                                                                
    a = ib.allocate(dtype, (1), name='a', scope='local')        
    b = ib.allocate(dtype, (1), name='b', scope='local')        
                                                                
    a[0] = outs[0].vload(idx, dtype)                            
    b[0] = outs[0].vload(idx, dtype)                            
                                                                
    if base_type.find('float') != -1:                           
        mad_func = lambda x, y: (x * x + y)                     
    else:                                                       
        mad_func = lambda x, y: y * y + x                       
                                                                
    for _ in range(item_per_thread // 4 // lanes):              
        a[0] = mad_func(a[0], b[0])                             
        b[0] = mad_func(b[0], a[0])                             
                                                                
    ib.emit(outs[0].vstore(idx, b[0]))                          
    return ib.get()                                             

y = tvm.extern((n,), [], extern, name="y", dtype=dtype)
s = tvm.create_schedule(y.op)                          
```
Is there a reason not to generate the key at the beginning and destroy it at the end?

> reason not to generate the key

No, but generating the key is [non-trivial](https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/how-to-create-self-signed-certificates-for-use-with-intel-sgx-remote-attestation-using)

Thanks

Regenerate the tensor flow graph with add_shapes=True.

This is an assumption to have _output_shapes for all nodes.

DepthwiseConv2dNative, FusedBatchNorm, Relu6.

I am working on mapping these operator to existing nnvm top.

Will share soon.

@merrymercy @eqy @kevinthesun @Laurawly @xqdan @ZihengJiang  @nhynes @Huyuwei 

Please read the hybrid script spec and participate the RFC discussion, we want to discuss the following questions:

## What is the preferred way of specifying bind thread syntax
1) explicit bind
```
for tx in bind("threadIdx.x", extent):
   pass
```
2) code mixing, similar to TVM convention
```
thread_x = thread_axis("thread", (0, extent))
for tx in bind(thread_x):
    pass
```

## What is the preferred way of naming the annotated loops
Currently, keywords are: unrolled, vectorized, serial, parallel.

Leaving the key in the repo means that it will be flagged by many security tools, even if the key is not used for anything but the demo. I think the simplest fix would be move the demo into a separate repo for demos and examples, which would let TVM itself not be flagged, but not require the work to generate the key each. I think long term we should probably generate the key each time.
If we just don't want any private key in TVM repo, a quick workaround might be create a gist to store the private key file.

Hmm. I wonder if a fake key can be auto-generated from random bytes instead. I'll look into that 

> many security tools

Which ones, exactly? Do they check the file extension or do they look in the file, itself?

High level question: within the hybrid style, are we abandoning the Halide-style "separation" of computation declaration and schedule optimization?

Thread bind syntax:
+ no real preference for me, though mixing allows different names to be chosen which can sometimes be confusing if different schedule writers have different naming styles

Naming annotated loops:
+ seems ok
@tqchen @piiswrong could you review the code again?
I tried all unit tests in tests/python/unittest and all of them work fine.

1, bind thread syntax: 
-  explicit bind is better for its simplicity

2, naming the annotated loops: 
- can we make serial as default so we can get ride of serial in interface, 
- we may use uniform style, with or without -ed, like unroll vectorize parallel

A new Features to discuss, 
For some complex ops, they may need STL in cuda c++, so can we have containers in python front end and then tvm lowers this into STL?
I think I've solved the problem, a PR is submitted #1228 to test ir_builder for gpu execution.

> bind thread syntax

I think that explicit is more readable since everything is in one place. If anyone wanted the code mixing style, they could always:
```python
thread_x = ('thread', extent)
for tx in bind(*thread_x):
    pass
```

> naming the annotated loops

All sound good except "serial." Although the terminology makes sense, I've never referred to a `for` loop as being serial--it's just the default. +1 to @xqdan 's proposal for default serial.

> intrinsics

Any plans for user-defined intrinsics a la `tvm.contrib`? Perhaps anything in the `tvm.contrib` namespace could also be auto-imported.
